title: Irene Davis' research on biomechanics and running injuries
content: Irene describes how her research of biomechanics and clinical work with running injuries, as well as research by others, has shaped her views on maintaining body alignment and foot health. Irene discusses her argument for the role of modern footwear in running-related injuries and how minimalist footwear helps resolve the subsequent biomechanical issues.

title: Physiology of a stress response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: Individual variation in the response to stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the individual variation in the response to stress, and how everyone has a different optimal level. He also talks about how social rank and personality differences affect our stress response.

title: Tips for managing stress in the modern world
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world.

title: The impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Irene's path to her Ph.D. and her interest in biomechanics
content: Irene completed a degree in physical therapy and went on to complete a master’s degree and Ph.D. in biomechanics. She completed her Ph.D. at Penn State under Dr. Peter Kavanaugh, who is a pioneer of running mechanics.

title: What shifted Irene’s interest towards biomechanics
content: Irene's interest in biomechanics shifted when she realized that quadriplegics need to move their entire body with just 25% of their muscle – they need to learn to use their bodies in atypical ways.

title: How Irene’s thinking about the use of orthotics has changed
content: Irene's thinking about the use of orthotics changed based on her research and when the book Born to Run was published. Her research led her to realize that people who land on their heels while running incur greater impact forces, and that footwear influences these forces. The permanent nature of orthotics is the opposite of the approach of removing support to encourage patients to improve their intrinsic ability.

title: The evolution of the human foot and the transition from walking to running
content: Anatomical changes from walking man (Australopithecus) to running man (Homo erectus) include joint surfaces becoming larger to bear greater forces, the longitudinal and medial longitudinal arches developing, and the achilles tendon becoming longer for greater energy storage. The foot has 26 bones, 33 articulations, and six degrees of freedom, resulting in a complex structure.

title: The Evolution of Shoes and its Impact on Running Injuries
content: Humans have been running for 2 million years. The earliest known shoes date back to 10,000 years ago. Prior to the 1960s, running footwear was similar to what is sold as minimalist shoes today. Running injuries did not appear in the research literature, or at least not nearly as much, until approximately when these specialized shoes appeared.

title: An Overview of Running Injuries
content: Running injuries are most commonly from the knee down, but can go all the way up to the neck. The reason why most injuries occur from the knee down is because this is where most shock absorption occurs. Landing incurs a force that is 2.5 to 3 times body weight. At the knee, this force can be 7 times body weight.

title: Cushioned Running Shoes, Heel Striking and Impact Forces
content: Studies have shown that people create greater landing force in the HOKA shoe. A study has shown that the heel has a relatively low pain threshold that doesn’t extend far beyond the level of force generated during walking—suggesting that we have evolved to be forefoot strikers. Most barefoot runners are forefoot strikers. An advantage of heel striking is that it allows for a longer stride and therefore greater speed, and on softer surfaces, this might be reasonable.

title: Shin Splints
content: One of the most common injuries that runners have when they first start running is an “overuse” injury called shin splints. Shin splints manifest as pain in the front of the lower leg. The primary muscle where this occurs, the tibialis anterior, is much smaller than the muscles in the back of the lower leg. Because of the smaller size, the tibialis anterior is more prone to the fatigue and overuse that can result in shin splints.

title: How Heel Strike Patterns Promotes Knee Stress Through Rate of Loading
Impact forces and injury potential
content: Heel striking leads to a more rapid rate of vertical force development. Forefoot striking in minimalist shoes decreases the rate of force development.

title: How shoe cushioning alters impact forces despite forefoot striking
content: Forefoot striking in cushioned shoes promotes landing with more plantar flexion, which exposes the Achilles tendon to greater stress. It also promotes landing on the outside of the foot, which causes an increase in lateral forces. This tends to result in problems in both the Achilles and peroneal tendons.

title: Considerations for shoe selection
content: Forefoot striking should be done in minimalist shoes. People who choose to remain heel strikers should wear cushioned shoes.

title: An overview of minimalist shoes
content: When I talk about minimal, I’m talking about a shoe you can roll up and put in your pocket. Three brands of minimalist shoes that you can roll up and put in your pocket are Vivobarefoot, Xero, and Inov-8. A major problem with partial minimalist shoes is that they still encourage people to heel strike, but with less cushion.

title: Minimalist Shoes and Injuries
content: In one study, partial minimal shoes were associated with twice as much injuries as fully minimalist shoes. People who run in these shoes should learn to forefoot strike with a minimalist shoe, and if they do not want to, Irene suggests that they use fully cushioned shoes and replace them every 300-500 miles.

title: Transitioning Out of Orthotics
content: Irene’s protocol for transitioning people out of orthotics involves a gradual approach, over the course of 2-3 weeks. Irene has people initially keep their orthotics with them and gradually increase time without them – for example, the first half mile of a three-mile walk. Once someone can regularly walk comfortably without orthotics, she has them transition to minimalist shoes. A study led by Sarah Ridge from BYU has shown simply walking in minimalist shoes to be as effective as a dedicated foot-strengthening program.

title: Transitioning to Minimalist Shoes and a Forefoot Strike
content: Transitioning to minimalist shoes and a forefoot strike is a one to three month process, depending on age. Focus spans to include foot, hip, and knee function. Activities like hopping, lunging, and jumping rope are included to develop dynamic movement skill. Only after basic movement function has been developed does treadmill training start. Someone should be able to handle a 30-minute brisk walk with forefoot strike and minimalist shoes before starting on a treadmill. Otherwise, consequences include plantar fasciitis and metatarsal stress fracture.

title: Foot Muscle Volume, Minimalist Shoes, and Orthotics
content: Irene’s team did a study (Chen et al., 2016) showing that cross sectional volume of foot muscles is larger in people who run with minimalist shoes. Another study has shown that people who start wearing orthotics experience a decrease in foot muscle volume.

title: Minimalist Shoes Across the Lifespan
content: Irene believes minimalist shoes are important for kids so that their feet develop properly. Since we lose muscle power with age, and in the feet and lower extremities first, Irene also believes that transitioning to minimalist shoes is important for adults. Courses/programs related to training forefoot strike: Pose Method & ChiRunning.

title: Why Learning to Forefoot Strike on Soft Surfaces is Not the Best Approach
content: Running barefoot has the benefit of maximizing sensory input from ground contact. Running on grass barefoot is not a good idea because you may not see things that will injure your foot. Soft surfaces in general will encourage more stiffness throughout the body. In contrast, harder surfaces will encourage a softer landing.

title: Knee Valgus and Factors Related to Knee Injury
content: Poor movement pattern is not always the cause of injuries. While someone with poor movement will likely be injured more quickly, someone with good movement still has increased injury risk if their dose of movement is too high. Poor movement can manifest as injury in different ways – for example, knee valgus might cause knee pain, but it may instead cause hip pain. Instability of foot muscles, or the “foot core” as she calls it, is a cause of knee valgus.

title: IT Band Syndrome
content: N/A

title: IT Band Syndrome
content: The iliotibial band (or IT band for short) connects the tensor fasciae latae to the lateral (outside) part of the tibia at the knee. Irene’s group has done both prospective and retrospective studies on people with history of IT band syndrome, and in both cases found greater inward angulation of the thigh, which stretches the IT band. Inward rotation of the tibia was also found in these studies, which is associated with pronation (rolling in) of the foot, also stretches the IT band. Based on the above mechanisms, IT band syndrome can originate from the hip or the foot. Peter was able to eliminate his IT band pain through eccentric strengthening of his gluteus medius.

title: Gait Retraining
content: Gait retraining in Irene’s clinic. Irene’s ideas of being able to retrain gait in runners was met with skepticism during the early years of her career. It is now known that gait can be reprogrammed. Gait retraining requires a lot of practice, however. It is not easy to retrain a movement pattern that has been engrained for decades. Feedback is helpful, but must eventually be faded out. In Irene’s lab, the process involves an average of two months spent working on gait, four weeks of gait training on the treadmill, and then 10 weeks of supervised incremental increases in running.

title: Minimalist Shoes
content: A physician in a closed Christian community, inspired by the book Born to Run, resolved his own foot problems by running barefoot and in minimalist shoes. He gradually started recommending it to members of the community’s track team who had season-ending injuries and weren’t responding to standard of care. Eventually, 80% of the community was wearing minimalist shoes, and referrals to podiatrists decreased as use of minimalist shoes increased. The community’s cross country team ended up completing a season with no injuries and winning their division. They were bumped up to the next division, where they also did well, possibly finishing as high as second.

title: Importance of Proper Movement Patterns
content: Peter and Irene believe that frequent sitting and wearing of shoes present a major challenge for maintaining proper movement in today’s society. Irene suggests that gym class in schools should be every day and should involve more demanding movement including calisthenics.

title: Chronic Conditions in Adolescents
content: About 31% of adolescents aged 12 to 17 have at least one chronic condition, according to a report from the National Adolescent and Young Adult Health Information Center.

title: Encouraging Kids to Play Multiple Sports
content: Irene believes that sport specificity can present problems and that kids should be encouraged to play multiple sports.
